CatDescriptText: Jeannette Croson, dental aide, Homewood and Norman Edison, mechanic, Hill District, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 27, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe that labor unions, in general, are doing all they can to see that Negroes are not discriminated against in hiring and upgrading in employment?"  Mrs. Croson's answer reads: It's improving, because things are better than they used to be.  But, still there is more which can be done."  Mr. Edison's answer reads: "I wouldn't say that they are doing all that they can.  They really have given the colored man a break.  But it is not the break that he deserves, but better than what he was getting before."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Jeannette Croson wearing light colored tweed jacket, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Norman Edison wearing sunglasses and light colored jacket with patch inscribed "McCray Commercial Refrigeration", standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
